Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Patient ID: [REDACTED]
Date of procedure: [REDACTED]
Attending physician: Dr. P. Hart
Assistants: Interventional pulmonology fellow; bronchoscopy nurse; radiology technologist.

Pre-procedure diagnosis: 22 mm left upper lobe posterior segment nodule in close proximity to segmental vessels.
Post-procedure diagnosis: Same.
Indication: Local tumor control via transbronchial radiofrequency ablation in a high-risk surgical patient.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.0 mm endotracheal tube; ASA class III.

Procedures performed:
1. Electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy with radial EBUS confirmation.
2. Transbronchial cooled radiofrequency ablation of left upper lobe nodule.

Procedure description: The navigation bronchoscope was used to reach the posterior segment bronchus, and radial EBUS confirmed an eccentric lesion adjacent to a vessel. A cooled RFA catheter was positioned within the nodule under fluoroscopic guidance. Energy was applied in two overlapping 8-minute cycles with catheter rotation between cycles to avoid hot spots near the vessel. Interval cone-beam CT showed a uniform ablation zone encasing the lesion with preservation of nearby major vessels. Final imaging demonstrated an approximate 6 mm minimal margin around the nodule. Endoscopic inspection showed no significant bleeding or airway compromise.

Estimated blood loss: <10 mL.
Complications: None immediate.
Disposition: Extubated in the operating room and admitted overnight for observation; scheduled follow-up CT and multidisciplinary discussion at tumor board.
